TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract sealed beforefieldinit WebUtility extends System.Object
public ref class WebUtility abstract sealed

Docs.summary: Provides methods for encoding and decoding URLs when processing Web requests.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.HttpUtility> class contains encoding and decoding utility methods for use with HTML-encode strings. The <xref:System.Uri?displayProperty=nameWithType> class also contains methods and properties that can be used for similar purposes.

Docs.related: How to: Protect Against Script Exploits in a Web Application by Applying HTML Encoding to Strings

Docs.summary: Converts a string that has been HTML-encoded for HTTP transmission into a decoded string.

MemberSignature.Value: public static string HtmlDecode (string value);
.method public static hidebysig string HtmlDecode(string value) cil managed
Public Shared Function HtmlDecode (value As String) As String
public: static System::String ^ HtmlDecode(System::String ^ value);
static member HtmlDecode : string -> string

Docs.summary: Converts a string that has been HTML-encoded for HTTP transmission into a decoded string.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If characters such as blanks and punctuation are passed in an HTTP stream, they might be misinterpreted at the receiving end. HTML encoding converts characters that are not allowed in HTML into character-entity equivalents; HTML decoding reverses the encoding. For example, when embedded in a block of text, the characters `<` and `>` are encoded as `<` and `>` for HTTP transmission.
If the `value` parameter is `null`, then the returned decoded string is `null`. If the `value` parameter is an empty string, then the returned decoded string is an empty string.

MemberSignature.Value: public static void HtmlDecode (string value, System.IO.TextWriter output);
.method public static hidebysig void HtmlDecode(string value, class System.IO.TextWriter output) cil managed
Public Shared Sub HtmlDecode (value As String, output As TextWriter)
public: static void HtmlDecode(System::String ^ value, System::IO::TextWriter ^ output);
static member HtmlDecode : string * System.IO.TextWriter -> unit

Docs.summary: Converts a string that has been HTML-encoded into a decoded string, and sends the decoded string to a output stream.

remarks.format: ## Remarks If characters such as blanks and punctuation are passed in an HTTP stream, they might be misinterpreted at the receiving end. HTML encoding converts characters that are not allowed in HTML into character-entity equivalents; HTML decoding reverses the encoding. For example, when embedded in a block of text, the characters `<` and `>` are encoded as `<` and `>` for HTTP transmission.

HTML encoding converts characters that are not allowed in HTML into character-entity equivalents; HTML decoding reverses the encoding. For example, when embedded in a block of text, the characters `<` and `>` are encoded as `<` and `>` for HTTP transmission.
If the `value` parameter is `null`, then the returned encoded string is `null`. If the `value` parameter is an empty string, then the returned encoded string is an empty string.

HTML encoding converts characters that are not allowed in HTML into character-entity equivalents; HTML decoding reverses the encoding. For example, when embedded in a block of text, the characters `<` and `>` are encoded as `<` and `>` for HTTP transmission.

public: static System::String ^ UrlDecode(System::String ^ encodedValue);
static member UrlDecode : string -> string

Docs.summary: Converts a string that has been encoded for transmission in a URL into a decoded string.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If characters such as blanks and punctuation are passed in an HTTP stream, they might be misinterpreted at the receiving end. URL encoding converts characters that are not allowed in a URL into equivalent hexadecimal escape sequences. The <xref:System.Net.WebUtility.UrlEncode%2A> method creates a URL-encoded string.
URL decoding replaces hexadecimal escape sequences with corresponding ASCII character equivalents. For example, when embedded in a block of URL-encoded text, the escape sequences `%3c` and `%3e` are decoded into the characters `<` and `>`.

MemberSignature.Value: public static byte[] UrlDecodeToBytes (byte[] encodedValue, int offset, int count);
.method public static hidebysig unsigned int8[] UrlDecodeToBytes(unsigned int8[] encodedValue, int32 offset, int32 count) cil managed

public: static cli::array <System::Byte> ^ UrlDecodeToBytes(cli::array <System::Byte> ^ encodedValue, int offset, int count);
static member UrlDecodeToBytes : byte[] * int * int -> byte[]

Docs.param: The offset, in bytes, from the start of the array to decode.
The count, in bytes, to decode from the array.
Docs.summary: Converts an encoded byte array that has been encoded for transmission in a URL into a decoded byte array.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If characters such as blanks and punctuation are passed in an HTTP stream, they might be misinterpreted at the receiving end. URL encoding converts characters that are not allowed in a URL into equivalent hexadecimal escape sequences. The <xref:System.Net.WebUtility.UrlEncodeToBytes%2A> method creates a URL-encoded byte array.
URL decoding replaces hexadecimal escape sequences with corresponding ASCII character equivalents. For example, when embedded in a block of URL-encoded text, the escape sequences `%3c` and `%3e` are decoded into the characters `<` and `>`.

public: static System::String ^ UrlEncode(System::String ^ value);
static member UrlEncode : string -> string

Docs.summary: Converts a text string into a URL-encoded string.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If characters such as blanks and punctuation are passed in an HTTP stream, they might be misinterpreted at the receiving end. URL encoding replaces characters that are not allowed in a URL with character-entity equivalents consisting of hexadecimal escape sequences. The converted string is expected to conform to the UTF-8 format.
URL encoding replaces all character codes except for letters, numbers, and the following punctuation characters:
- `-` (minus sign)
- `_` (underscore)
- `.` (period)
- `!` (exclamation point)
- `*` (asterisk)
- `(` and `)` (opening and closing parentheses)
For example, when embedded in a block of text to be transmitted in a URL, the characters `<` and `>` are encoded as `%3c` and `%3e`.
The <xref:System.Net.WebUtility.UrlDecode%2A> method reverses the encoding.

MemberSignature.Value: public static byte[] UrlEncodeToBytes (byte[] value, int offset, int count);
.method public static hidebysig unsigned int8[] UrlEncodeToBytes(unsigned int8[] value, int32 offset, int32 count) cil managed
Public Shared Function UrlEncodeToBytes (value As Byte(), offset As Integer, count As Integer) As Byte()
public: static cli::array <System::Byte> ^ UrlEncodeToBytes(cli::array <System::Byte> ^ value, int offset, int count);
static member UrlEncodeToBytes : byte[] * int * int -> byte[]

Docs.param: The offset, in bytes, from the start of the array to encode.
The count, in bytes, to encode from the array.
Docs.summary: Converts a byte array into a URL-encoded byte array.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If characters such as blanks and punctuation are passed in an HTTP stream, they might be misinterpreted at the receiving end. URL encoding replaces characters that are not allowed in a URL with character-entity equivalents consisting of hexadecimal escape sequences. The converted string is expected to conform to the UTF-8 format.
URL encoding replaces all character codes except for letters, numbers, and the following punctuation characters:
- `-` (minus sign)
- `_` (underscore)
- `.` (period)
- `!` (exclamation point)
- `*` (asterisk)
- `'` (single quotation mark)
- `(` and `)` (opening and closing parentheses)
For example, when embedded in a block of text to be transmitted in a URL, the characters `<` and `>` are encoded as `%3c` and `%3e`.
The <xref:System.Net.WebUtility.UrlDecodeToBytes%2A> method reverses the encoding.
